Microsoft (MSFT) CEO Satya Nadella beat out such tech icons as Amazon.com (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos and Tesla Motors (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk to be named the most influential executive in the tech industry, according to a ranking by Juniper Research.Juniper picked Nadella for its highly subjective top 10 list based on his moves to transform Microsoft to a mobile and cloud computing company from one centered on PCs.Juniper based its tech leader rankings on its assessment of eight key criteria such as "vision, innovation and personal capital." It announced the rankings on Wednesday.The research firm said Nadella's implementation of "Windows-as-a-Service" represented a fundamental change to Microsoft's business model, resulting in a very different process of development at the Redmond, Wash.-based software company.For second place, Juniper chose Apple's (AAPL) newly appointed Chief Design Officer Jony Ive. Juniper said Ive's design of the Apple Watch is the new benchmark for the smartwatch category.Third place went to Min-Liang Tan, co-founder and CEO of video game products company Razer. Juniper noted Tan's involvement in the OSVR (Open Source Virtual Reality) platform.Fourth place went to Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick. Uber is undercutting traditional taxi services in multiple locations, notably in New York City, where its ride-sharing cars outnumber the city's famous yellow taxis.Fifth place went to Netflix (NFLX) co-founder and CEO Reed Hastings, who has supervised the company's aggressive international expansion and move into original content creation.Sixth through 10th places went (in descending order) to Alibaba Group (BABA) founder and Chairman Jack Ma, Google (GOOGL) Advanced Technologies and Products Director Paul Eremenko, Amazon's Bezos, Tesla's Musk, and Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun.

Investors will look for commentary on potential growth in China and other business drivers when Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) report their March ending quarters this week, MasterCard on Wednesday morning and Visa late Thursday.
Shares of the two giant card networks jumped last week on news that China would soon give foreign card companies access to its bank clearing system, essentially ending China UnionPay's monopoly.
Both stocks have been climbing the last few years. In particular, they have jumped after strong earnings reports in the prior two quarters.

For its fiscal Q2 quarter ending in March, Visa's earnings are expected to see a rare decline, however, by 2% to 62 cents a share, largely due to an unusual tax benefit in the same quarter a year earlier, which helped lift earnings 31% then.
Analysts expect Visa's next two quarters to resume double-digit growth, however — 20% and 24%, respectively — and end the year up 14%, according to a Thomson Reuters poll.
MasterCard's earnings are seen rising 10% in Q1 to 80 cents a share and ending the year up 12%.
Visa is an IBD Leaderboard stock, one of a select group of companies seen having potential for bigger gains.
Visa tried to break out last week on the China news, briefly hitting a new high before settling for more modest gains. The stock is currently about 3% below its buy point and all-time high.
Visa is seen benefitting from strong bank issuing partnerships, especially JPMorgan Chase (JPM) in credit cards.
And next April, it will start processing cards issued by Citigroup (C) for Costco Wholesale (COST), replacing American Express (AXP).

MasterCard also shot up last week on the China news, coming close to a record high. The stock has been consolidating for the past few sessions, about 3% off the Feb. 26 high of 93.Investors will look for commentary on potential growth in China and other business drivers when Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) report their March ending quarters this week, MasterCard on Wednesday morning and Visa late Thursday.Shares of the two giant card networks jumped last week on news that China would soon give foreign card companies access to its bank clearing system, essentially ending China UnionPay's monopoly.Both stocks have been climbing the last few years. Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) shares retreated from record highs Tuesday on news that the Chinese online messaging giant Chairman and CEO Pony Ma Huateng sold 20 million shares over two days last week

Tencent, which is listed in Hong Kong but trades over the counter in the U.S., fell fell 5.5% on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. In the U.S., Tencent slid 4.2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. However, volume was lighter than average and shares are stil above their 10-day moving average.
Tencent has been on a tear since reporting a 50% fourth-quarter earnings gain on March 18. Since then, U.S. shares rose 25% to Monday, setting record highs.

On Monday, Tencent topped a $200 billion market cap. Its archrival, Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA), has a market cap of $209.7 billion. But Alibaba's stock has tumbled 30% since its Nov. 14 peak of 120, finding resistance at the 50-day moving average. Alibaba counterfeit goods have become an issue again as the Chinese giant, bowing to U.S. government pressure over an apparel trade group's complaint, said Tuesday it's stepping up efforts vs. fake goods.

Tencent CEO Ma trimmed his stake to 9.65% from 9.86% after the sales, which raised $415 million. Tencent told the Hong Kong Economic Journal the the sales had nothing to do with the company's outlook. But investors still took the news as a reason to take profits in Tencent and perhaps the Hang Seng Index, which fell 1.7% on Tuesday.

Tencent is best known for its WeChat and QQ messaging services, which help fuel mobile gaming revenue. Tencent's services also help forge alliances to take on Alibaba on its e-commerce turf. Its own a significant stake in JD.com (JD), an Amazon.com-like e-commerce giant. JD.com shares fell 3% Tuesday afternoon after climbing nearly 16% over the past seven sessions to a record high.
Tencent and JD.com recently bought stakes in BitAuto (BITA). BitAuto is a leading auto information site.

Tencent also owns a significant stake in 58.com (WUBA), a Craigslist-like classifieds site. 58.com shares soared 27.2% to 64.66 Tuesday afternoon, hitting a record high, on reports that 58.com is in merger talks with rival Ganji.com.

Stocks held moderate gains going into the noon hour Wednesday, with energy stocks leading the way on a sharp rise in oil prices. The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 rose 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average lifted 0.8% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking higher than at the same time Tuesday on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.

Among IBD's 197 industry groups, energy groups were among the best performers. The U.S. oil and gas producers group rose 6%. Oil futures rose more than 3% after the government said oil stockpiles declined unexpectedly, signaling a rare reprieve from the oversupply that has driven down prices. OPEC also said it expects oil prices to rebound.

Despite a cheery earnings report and an after-hours pop Tuesday, Nike (NKE) reversed and headed lower. It was down 2% in above-average volume and struggled to hold its 50-day moving average even though several analysts had good words for the stock before the open. It's trading below a 133.62 buy point it cleared a few weeks ago.

Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) gapped down and was trading at a four-year low, off more than 4%. Before the open, Wedbush Morgan lowered its price target on the stock to 48 from 62. The stock has broken below 50, to the lowest since August 2011.
Among IBD 50 stocks, Veeva Systems (VEEV), a newcomer to the list, was the best performer, up 2%. The cloud-based medical software maker is forming a long base.
Another IBD 50 newcomer, electric utility ITC (ITC), also rose 2% and is forming a base. It has received multiple analyst upgrades in recent weeks.

Stamps.com (STMP) hit a 15-year high and is now extended from a flat base from which it broke out Dec. 15. Apple Pay has jumped ahead of eBay's PayPal and Google (GOOGL) for in-store mobile payments, but PayPal's potential relationship with retailers makes it a strong contender in this field, says a Jefferies report.

Analyst Jason Kupferberg, commenting on Jefferies' Electronic Payments Summit in New York, wrote that credit card firms Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) remain well-positioned as Apple (AAPL), Internet companies and others target mobile payments.
"Apple Pay has been the most successful multimerchant mobile wallet to date, but usage is still quite limited," said Kupferberg. "PayPal's Paydiant acquisition could signal an MCX relationship."

Apple Pay, introduced in September as part of Apple's iPhone 6 launch, uses near-field communications, a short-range wireless technology, to send data to payment readers. But analysts say just 15% of U.S. retail locations have NFC-equipped sales terminals.

"Despite the buzz following the launch of Apple Pay and (Electronic Payments Summit) panelists' commentary speaking to significant inbound merchant interest, we believe that the limited consumer value proposition remains a headwind to widespread mobile wallet adoption in the near future," Kupferberg said.
Last month, Baird Equity Research estimated that 40% of iPhone 6 users had tried Apple Pay.

PayPal, which owner eBay (EBAY) plans to spin off this year, in March acquired Paydiant, which has close ties to a group of large retailers that have banded together as the Merchant Customer Exchange.

MCX expects to roll out a mobile wallet app in 2015, aiming to reduce the clout of credit card firms in the nascent mobile payment business, analysts say. Wal-Mart (WMT) is among the retailers backing MCX.

"We still await clarity on timing of MCX's CurrentC mobile wallet launch, and note there was chatter at the Summit about PayPal's recent acquisition of Paydiant possibly being a precursor to some tie-up between PayPal and MCX, which would benefit from PayPal's huge base of enrolled consumer accounts," Kupferberg said.

Costco Wholesale (COST) reported second-quarter earnings that topped Wall Street estimates on Thursday, but total revenue fell short.

The big box membership retailer said Q2 earnings rose 28.6% to $1.35. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.18. Total revenue, which includes membership fees, rose 4.4% to $27.45 billion, under views for $27.65 billion. Sales alone were up 4.3% to $26.78 billion.
Same-store sales were up 8%, above the 6.4% analysts at Consensus Metrix were expecting. February comps were up 1%. Costco's Q2 ended Feb. 15.
Shares were up 2.26% to 150.50 in pre-market trading on the stock market today.

Costco announced Monday it is partnering with Citigroup (C) and Visa (V) after talks to keep American Express (AXP) fell though last month. Costco and AmEx's partnership will end in March 2016 after 16 years. It had already dropped AmEx in Canada last year for a new deal with Capital One Financial (COF) and MasterCard (MA).

Stocks had trouble finding direction during the morning but were mildly higher going into the noon hour as a mixed bag of earnings reports dominated the action.
The Nasdaq rose less than 0.1%; the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.

Visa (V) rose 6% and MasterCard (MA) 4%, both in heavy volume. China said it would let foreign companies set up bank-card clearing operations, a field dominated by state-run UnionPay. The rules take effect June 1. Both stocks have been building flat bases.

Illumina (ILMN) was off 3%. It reported better-than-expected earnings of 91 cents a share, a 72% increase from a year ago and above the 72-cent estimate. The stock had traded higher in after-hours action after the earnings announcement Tuesday.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped down and was trading 7% lower. It topped estimates on earnings, but missed on sales.

After the close Tuesday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings and raised its 2015 earnings outlook.Illumina (ILMN) was off 3%. It reported better-than-expected earnings of 91 cents a share, a 72% increase from a year ago and above the 72-cent estimate. The stock had traded higher in after-hours action after the earnings announcement Tuesday.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped down and was trading 7% lower. It topped estimates on earnings, but missed on sales.Another restaurant stock, Yum Brands (YUM), broke out of a cup-with-handle base and rose 5%. Profit beat analysts' forecast, but same-store sales in China, the source of half the company's revenue, fell 12%.

On Thursday, Pacific Crest Securities said that Netflix's (NFLX) ambitions are becoming clearer and "more frightening" to traditional programmers. And if they weren't frightened then, they may have more reason to be now. Netflix is reportedly in talks to enter the China market, where there's a vast and still growing online audience. That could further fuel the video streaming service's…
Netflix stock surged to a record high Friday on reports that the subscription Internet television service is negotiating with partners to launch in China.
Netflix (NFLX) jumped 4.5% to close at 613.25. Intraday its shares notched an all-time high of 618.44. Year to date, Netflix stock is up 67%. In just the past four weeks, it has climbed 29%.

Netflix is in talks with several Chinese online broadcast firms to enter China through a partnership, according to reports by Bloomberg and the Wall Street Journal. Netflix has spoken with Shanghai-based BesTV New Media and Wasu Media, which is partially owned by Alibaba (BABA) founder Jack Ma.

A local partnership is necessary given the Chinese government's strict controls over online content. Talks are still in the early stages and issues like objectionable subject matter and restrictions on foreign content need to be worked out.

Censorship is a major hurdle for Netflix in China. The company is known for its envelope-pushing shows including the sex- and violence-filled political drama "House of Cards" and the prison drama "Orange Is the New Black," which touches on topics of crime and same-sex relationships.
Plans to start modestly
In a letter to investors in January, Netflix said that it hopes to "operate a small service in China centered on our original and other globally-licensed content."
CEO Reed Hastings said Netflix's operation in China will be "modest" at first.

"Because we won't have that much content, we're going to be very cautious and feel our way along through that process," Hastings told analysts on Jan. 20. Executives did not discuss China during Netflix's most recent quarterly conference call on April 15.
Netflix said it intends to complete its global expansion by the end of 2016.
Netflix ended the March quarter with 62.27 million subscribers worldwide. For the June quarter, Netflix expects to add 2.5 million subscribers.

It expects to be in 200 countries by the end of 2016. Netflix is in over 50 countries today, mostly in the Americas and Europe. It entered Australia and New Zealand in March and plans to be in Japan this fall.
Morningstar analyst Neil Macker told IBD that the reports about Netflix negotiating to enter China shouldn't come as a surprise, giving the company's signals this year.
"They're exploring their options, which everyone expected them to be doing," Macker said. "China is a huge market with a unique regulatory structure."
Netflix is likely talking to all seven companies in China that have root-level licenses for delivering online video in the country, he said.

Green Beret Bill Albracht feared that he would be bored to death when he took command of a tiny outpost in South Vietnam on Oct. 28, 1969. At 21, he was the youngest Special Forces captain in the war. And he was eager to experience his first combat.He was in charge of Firebase Kate on a hilltop on the Cambodian border, with 27 American artillerymen and 136 lightly armed Montagnard tribesmen. Intelligence said that any attacks would hit nearby Bu Prang Special Forces camp.Wrong. Just before midnight, upward of 5,000 North Vietnamese soldiers launched a four-day monsoon of fire and steel.Didn't Back Down"I never considered surrender," Albracht, co-author with Marvin Wolf of the new book "Abandoned in Hell," told IBD. "It wasn't something we trained for, but it was a matter of principle. We also knew we had killed and wounded so many of them that we probably wouldn't be treated too well if we were captured."Incredibly, he and most of his little band survived the onslaught, and he would leave Vietnam with three Purple Hearts, three Silver Stars and three Bronze Stars.Albracht, now 66, was born in 1948 in Rock Island, Ill., part of the Quad Cities metro area of northwest Illinois and southeast Iowa. It would be his home base for much of his life.He was the third of five kids with a mother who suffered from depression and a father who was a harsh disciplinarian. Bill met low expectations in high school, where he was voted "most fun to be with."He and a friend decided that it would be a great adventure to join the Army after graduation, even though in 1966 most of their peers were doing everything they could to avoid the Vietnam War.At basic training at Fort Campbell, Ky., Albracht was shocked to be told that he had passed the Officer Candidate School qualification test by a single point."It sounded like a lot of responsibility and not much fun," he said.He tried to get out of it, but the Army insisted.Albracht soon realized that his tough early life had helped him prepare. He completed the grueling infantry leadership course at Fort Benning, Ga., in August 1967 and was commissioned as a second lieutenant."I learned the most important lesson that applies to any career," he said. "A good leader has to first complete the mission, no matter what. Then he has to take care of those who enabled him to do this. Then he can accept any reward he has earned. Too often you find people at the top have these priorities reversed."After parachute training, he was surprised to be selected to attend the Special Warfare Center at Fort Bragg, N.C., to become a Green Beret. While he was nearly disqualified by the algebra and geometry required, he excelled out in the field.Now wearing the hat of the Army Special Forces, Albracht sought action. He wanted to go to Vietnam to join his older brother, Bob, a legend in the Green Berets.Army policy, however, barred risking the lives of siblings in the same theater. So Bill was shipped to Thailand to help its army with logistics. After volunteering for another year and rising to captain, Albracht finally landed in Vietnam during August 1969.Into The FrayHe was bound for command of a regular infantry company, where captains were in short supply, but persuaded his commander to send him to a Special Forces unit.Disappointment again hit him, this time because the job was at a headquarters desk.He wasn't about to sit still. He persuaded his commander to send him closer to the action — with a Special Forces A Team at Bu Prang in the Central Highlands.Even though the Army figured that the communist enemy was itching for an attack on the Bu Prang camp, Albracht was ordered to sleepy Firebase Kate. The outpost housed just three howitzers and their GI crews, with a Montagnard company for their security.Then came the October surprise. Gunfire woke Albracht at 11:30 p.m., and he barely slept in the next four days. In the first 24 hours, he was wounded but refused evacuation.The Air Force made dozens of attacks to drive back the North Vietnamese and take out their artillery. One of the Americans' most formidable air weapons was the AC-47 Spooky aerial gunship, which could fire up to 18,000 rounds a minute. But it flew at low altitudes and so made its runs only at night.Up Against ItKate had another problem. It was five miles from a road. The enemy assault was so ferocious, the only reinforcements for the American camp that could be delivered by helicopter were 40 more tribesmen.On Nov. 1, Albracht realized that Kate would soon be overrun. Fighting until death or capture served no strategic purpose. With reinforcement impossible, he asked local headquarters for permission to evacuate, which was denied.Certain that he didn't have enough ammo to withstand another major assault, Albracht responded by informing his commander that he and his men would attempt a near-impossible escape through enemy lines. The answer: Go for it."It seemed slightly less suicidal than staying," Albracht said. "We planned to leave that night, but trying to find our way through the jungle while avoiding the enemy didn't seem likely to succeed."Of the 27 Americans, nine had been wounded and evacuated by helicopter. The 18 remaining were joined by 126 Montagnards (some 20 had been killed, with 30 wounded and evacuated).About 7 p.m., they crept through the hellish landscape cratered by bombing, escaped a North Vietnamese machine gun ambush and barely avoided another large force.A Special Forces rescue team sent to guide them to safety was not where Albracht figured, but he found it at 11 p.m. and arrived at Bu Prang at 11 a.m. the next day.Here he was ready for comfort, sleeping 10 hours — when suddenly an enemy assault on the camp nearly killed him.Albracht joined the fray and helped beat back the communists.A few days later, he brought wounded men by helicopter to headquarters at Buon Ma Thuot.Albracht then volunteered for and joined the elite Mobile Strike Force and was wounded twice in the spring of 1970 — first during a battle at Dak Seang, then by mortar shrapnel while on the move with the MSF.In August, after recovering and manning a desk, he went home to the Quad Cities, having earned his Purple Hearts, Silver Stars, Bronze Stars and "the only award I truly coveted," the Combat Infantryman Badge."Bill succeeded in combat because he thoroughly prepared himself through study and training," said co-author Wolf, who served in Vietnam in 1965-66 and became a captain a year before Albracht. "He trusted his instincts and training to overcome all obstacles and deal with any situation. He also demonstrated then, and in his later career, the awareness of what he didn't know and the willingness to enlist the right specialist for the task at hand, displaying unfailing loyalty to those who earned his trust and inspiring their loyalty."Albracht retired from active duty in 1970 with the rank of captain.Then he began a new career that would draw on the lessons of combat leadership. He enrolled at Augustana College in Rock Island, Ill., graduating in 1975 with majors in business and sociology, and a minor in psychology.Presidential DetailThen he joined the Secret Service, moved to Washington, D.C., and over the next 25 years protected six presidents. He was also involved in anti-counterfeiting operations, which once almost cost him his life in New York City.Until he wrote his book and began talking with others involved in the battle at Firebase Kate, Albracht was confused about many of its details, locked away as a traumatic memory. He now believes that the result was more than the sum of the courage and combat skills of him and his men."I truly don't know how we escaped from Firebase Kate," he said. "It had to be the hand of God that guided us."
The latest bad news for American Express (AXP) came in a Brooklyn, N.Y., courthouse as a federal judge ruled that the credit card company's merchant rules violate antitrust law.

In a 150-page decision, U.S. District Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis agreed with the Department of Justice, as well as 17 states, which alleged that AmEx's merchant rules illegally restrained trade. The lawsuit, filed in 2010, went to trial last year.

AmEx bars businesses from asking their customers to use debit cards or other credit cards that carry lower merchant fees. Garaufis, whom President Bill Clinton nominated to the federal bench in 2000, said he will issue a penalty against American Express at a later time.

American Express shares fell 2.3% to 77.92 on the stock market today. The card firm hasn't traded above its 50-day moving average since Jan. 2 and its shares are down about 16% so far this year. AmEx currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 43, meaning that 57% of other publicly traded companies are outperforming it.

The New York-based credit card company argued that the higher fees promote competition by allowing it to compete with Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) as well as providing more generous services. Customers also may be less likely to use American Express credit cards if merchants express a preference for other cards, AmEx argued.
AmEx said it was disappointed in the ruling, and that "we believe the decision was wrong."
"The court's ruling will not provide any benefit to consumers and will, in fact, harm competition by further entrenching the two dominant networks," American Express said in a statement.

The judge's decision on Thursday comes about one week after the announcement that its exclusive partnership with Costco (COST) for a co-branded credit card will come to an end next year. JetBlue Airways (JBLU) also reportedly has decided to end its co-branding credit card agreement with AmEx.

The fees charged to merchants each time a consumer swipes his or her credit card — usually 2% to 5% of the purchase price — have become a contentious issue in recent years. In 2013, Visa and MasterCard agreed to pay $5.7 billion to settle a class action suit that alleged that credit card companies violated antitrust law via illegally high merchant fees.The latest bad news for American Express (AXP) came in a Brooklyn, N.Y., courthouse as a federal judge ruled that the credit card company's merchant rules violate antitrust law.In a 150-page decision, U.S. District Judge Nicholas G. The dot-com bubble burst had a lot to do with technology stock mutual funds' underperformance relative to the top two sectors — real estate and energy — as well as the S&P 500 during the past 15 years.Look at the result of investing $10,000 in the average tech mutual fund on Dec. 31, 1999. The sum would have shrunk to $9,896 by Feb. 10 this year, according to Morningstar Inc. data. But the same amount would have grown to $58,115 in the average domestic real estate fund, $45,490 in the average world energy fund and $18,772 in the S&P 500.Tech mutual funds have fared better since the stock market low of March 2009. They've generated a cumulative return of 88% since then vs. 78% for real estate funds, 16% for energy funds and 97% for the S&P 500.Fidelity Select IT Services Portfolio has provided investors an average annual return of 10.02% the past 15 years vs. 4.53% for the S&P 500. The fund, managed by Kyle Weaver since 2009, and the S&P 500 are up less than 1% year to date. The $860 million fund's recent holdings include Visa (V), MasterCard (MA) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH).Visa has an IBD Composite Rating of 93. Fiscal Q1 earnings rose 15%, beating analyst estimates. The credit card processing company's full-year earnings are seen growing 19%, slightly below their three-year average pace of 20%.MasterCard has a Composite Rating of 94. Q4 earnings rose 21%, surpassing estimates. Full-year earnings are expected to growth 13%, below the three-year rate of 18%.Cognizant has a Composite Rating of 99. Earnings in the past three quarters have slowed to a range of 12%-14% from 18%-22% the prior three periods. Analysts see 13% growth in the current quarter as well as the full year.The provider of tech services and business process outsourcing has been focusing on building its health care and life science practice.

Target (TGT) is reportedly close to finalizing a $20 million settlement with MasterCard over costs incurred from the big box retailer's 2013 data hack.The deal involves reimbursements to financial institutions for the issuance of new MasterCard (MA) debit and credit cards, as well as payments made as a result of fraudulent transactions, according to sources cited in a Wall Street Journal report late Tuesday.Target and MasterCard could announce the deal as soon as this week, the Journal noted, adding that the retailer and Visa (V) are also holding similar talks.Target shares climbed initially but fell 0.2% in early afternoon trading on the stock market today after finding support at the 10-day line on Tuesday.MasterCard and Visa shares fell a fraction.Last month Target agreed to pay a $10 million class-action lawsuit settlement involving customers whose personal information may have been stolen as a result of the breach, which occurred during the holiday shopping season of 2013.An estimated 70 million customers had their personal data stolen, and 40 million more customers had their debit and credit accounts compromised.And with other high-profile attacks since, including Sony (SNE), Home Depot (HD) and JPMorgan (JPM), companies are boosting spending on cybersecurity software.The Computer Software-Security group is ranked No. 9 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks. The group is led by Palo Alto Networks (PANW), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Qualys (QLYS), all of which have a highest-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. Palo Alto and CyberArk got positive mentions in an Oppenheimer analyst note late Tuesday. CyberArk rose 4% intraday, Palo Alto 0.2% and Qualys 0.2%.That means their shares outperform 99% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative price performance.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.

As President Obama is expected to announce new cybersecurity initiatives at a Palo Alto summit on Friday, Visa (V) is doing away with traditional account numbers, while MasterCard (MA) is launching a way to let customers verify transactions using markers such as their voices and fingerprints.Visa shares were trading down nearly all morning, off about 0.2% before noon in the stock market today. Likewise, MasterCard shares were off 0.6%.Visa said it is broadening efforts to replace 16-digit account numbers with Visa Token Service, in which a "unique series of numbers" can authorize payments without giving away sensitive information. More than 500 financial institutions already employ the technology.Meanwhile, MasterCard plans to plunk down more than $20 million in new technology on programs such as the MasterCard Safety Net, which will monitor and block certain transactions in order to add another layer of security to accounts. The company will also introduce a program later this year that will allow credit card holders to authenticate and verify transactions using biometrics such as fingerprint matching and facial and voice recognition.Home Depot (HD) and Target (TGT) are just two companies, popular with money card users, that have experienced notable cybersecurity breaches resulting in the leak of millions of customers' personal information.In the cybersecurity finances arena, CyberArk (CYBR) soundly beat sales and earnings views Thursday; its shares were up 17.5% before noon Friday. FireEye (FEYE) got a number of price target boosts on view-topping Q4 results and its shares were up another 5%. Cybersecurity stocks VeriSign (VRSN) was up 0.8% midday Friday and Qualys (QLYS) shares were down 1.5%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.

Global Payments (GPN) shares gapped up to a new all-time high after the electronic payments processor reported better than expected third-quarter earnings and announced a $100 million accelerated share buyback plan.
The gains come as the company executes a growth strategy that includes a recent acquisition in Europe that broadens its footprint there.

Earnings per share minus one-time items for the Atlanta-based company climbed 19% in Q3 to $1.14 on an 8.2% increase in revenue to $666.9 million. It was the seventh quarter in a row of better than expected earnings growth.
Analysts expected $1.11 EPS on $668.3 million in revenue.
The company maintained its outlook for full-year revenue of $2.75 billion to $2.8 billion, which would be up 8% to 10% from the prior year and about in line with consensus.
Global Payments also raised its outlook for full fiscal 2015 EPS to $4.77-$4.84, or 16% to 18% growth over 2014, topping views for $4.78.

CEO Jeff Sloan said the growth reflects "our strategy to deliver technology-enabled payments solutions across an expansive direct customer base worldwide, while continuing to invest in future growth."

Among its recent growth initiatives, Global Payments on March 25 announced it had purchased Realex Payments, a Dublin-based payments company that provides a range of technologies for businesses selling online, for about $125 million.

Like other payments processors such as MasterCard (MA), vehicle fleet payments card processor Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) and Visa (V), whose stock is on the IBD Leaderboard list of top performers, Global Payments is benefiting as more confident consumers and business step up credit card use.
Visa reports Q2 performance April 30.
Global Payments shares were up nearly 7% to 98.64 in heavy volume in afternoon trading in the stock market today.

After consolidating in the first half of calendar 2014, its stock rose above the range and it's climbed 38% from an October low. It boasts an 89 IBD Composite Rating, meaning its stock has outperformed 89% of all stocks on key metrics.
Visa and MasterCard were both up about 1% and Fleetcor rose 0.5%.

Stocks strengthened in mixed volume going into the final hour of trading Wednesday. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.6%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lighter on the Nasdaq in the stock market today.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose more than 5%. The company said in an email to analysts and investors it will unveil a home battery and a "very large" utility-scale battery April 30. The company has reported three straight quarters of declining earnings growth.

Wabtec (WAB) rose more than 2%, but had been up much higher earlier. The maker of railroad equipment reported earnings and revenue that beat estimates and the company raised 2015 guidance. The stock broke out of a flat base.
Facebook (FB) was up less than 1% as traders awaited earnings after the close. Analysts are expecting 40 cents a share, an 18% increase from a year ago.

Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) both rose 4% in heavy volume. China said it would let foreign companies set up bank-card clearing operations, a field dominated by state-run UnionPay. The rules take effect June 1. Both stocks have been building flat bases.

Amgen (AMGN) broke out of a cup-with-handle base, but gains quickly faded, leaving it less than 1% higher. Late Tuesday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings and raised its 2015 earnings outlook.

Illumina (ILMN) was off 5%. It reported better-than-expected earnings of 91 cents a share, a 72% increase from a year ago and above the 72-cent estimate. The stock initially surged on the results in Tuesday's after-hours session.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped down and was trading 7% lower. It topped estimates on earnings but missed on sales.Stocks strengthened in mixed volume going into the final hour of trading Wednesday. Casino resort giant Caesars Entertainment is betting on Vasco Data Security International's multifactor authentication technology to provide an extra layer of security — beyond just username and password — to help prevent hackers from sneaking into its networks.Vasco's (VDSI) recently introduced Cronto authentication and transaction-signing technology is being used by Dutch multinational financial service company Rabobank to improve security, via camera-equipped Rabo Scanner card readers. Vasco's technology provides a graphical cryptogram representing a transaction. When a picture of it is taken and then decoded, customers can securely view financial details on a computer, smartphone or tablet and then authorize the transaction."Our Cronto technology uses a high-definition color QR (Quick Response) code to deliver a hack-proof method of logging in and signing, which makes the process easier for users by having them perform fewer steps than they do today," Vasco CEO T. Kendall Hunt told IBD.In March, Vasco's electronic transaction signing technology was selected by Japanese megabank Mizuho Bank to help protect online banking transactions from hacking attacks.Caesars Entertainment (CZR), Rabobank and Mizuho Bank are among Vasco's 10,000-plus customers in 100 countries.Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.-based Vasco provides authentication and e-signature products and services, specializing in securing online accounts, managing identities and transactions, and protecting assets across financial, enterprise, e-commerce, government and health-care markets."Much of Vasco's success has been in the online banking vertical, and many banks are upgrading to their next-generation multi-factor authentication and e-signature products," said Dougherty & Co. analyst Joseph Maxa."In addition, they have a new product for securing mobile banking applications," Maxa said. "They're having success in Europe and Asia-Pacific, and several U.S. banks are using or evaluating their mobile products."Some 95% of Web app attacks make use of compromised credentials, including stolen user names and passwords, according to Verizon Communications' (VZ) 2015 Data Breach Investigations Report.More than 2.4 billion users are expected to embrace mobile banking services by 2020, compared to roughly 800 million in 2014, market tracking firm Research and Markets said in an April report.Growth DriversVasco says more than half of the top 100 global banks use its products and services to protect mobile applications, meet regulatory requirements and enhance overall security. Vasco also secures access to data and applications in the cloud, and provides tools for application developers to integrate security functions into Web-based and mobile applications.Hunt says a confluence of factors is driving its growth: Enterprises need more effective defenses against increasingly sophisticated cyberattacks, users want security but also convenience, and there's growth in mobile applications."Our (security) solutions have been battle tested in the most extreme hacking environment — banking — and we believe they will have appeal in many other segments," Hunt told IBD.Las Vegas-based Caesars, with some 50 casinos plus resorts and other properties, turned to Vasco for software that enables a user's mobile phone to serve as a secure authentication device.William Worthington, Caesars' chief information security officer, says it wanted an additional authentication layer while not making it too complex for corporate users."Having a mobile solution makes it simple for employees to comply with a much higher level of security," Worthington said.Rabobank looked to Vasco's Digipass technology, with a one-time password that changes every 30 seconds, to enable a large-scale rollout of secure card readers that meet EMV (Europay, MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V) standards. Rabobank customers can do e-banking and secure e-commerce with Rabobank's secure smart card readers.Banks, retailers and other merchants in the U.S. are readying to support chip-enabled payment cards by an October 2015 EMV deadline, which shifts liability for fraudulent transactions to whichever entity involved has not yet adopted chip technology.Rabobank's purchases alone accounted for more than 30% of Vasco's Q1 revenue, Vasco noted in its Q1 earnings report on April 28 that beat Wall Street expectations.Vasco's Q1 earnings per share excluding items was 34 cents, up 278% from a year earlier. Revenue increased 68% to $65.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS ex items of 21 cents and $54.5 million in revenue.Vasco's Q1 results were spurred by an 83% increase in revenue from the banking market, as financial institutions spend on new software and hardware products, particularly payment card readers. Card readers represented 45% of Q1 revenue, vs. 21% a year earlier.Some 73% of Vasco's Q1 revenue came from the Europe-Middle East-Africa region, and 17% came from Asia, while the U.S. accounted for just 4%, and 6% was from other countries. Vasco boosted its full-year 2015 revenue guidance to a range of between $230 million and $240 million, up from a prior range of $220 million to $230 million, citing "a strong pipeline of potential new orders" for its traditional and new authentication and anti-fraud products. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters now forecast full-year 2015 revenue of $237.6 million.Vasco faces a wide range of competitors, including more direct rivals such as RSA Security, which is a subsidiary of EMC Corp. (EMC), and Gemalto, as well as other indirect competition from companies such as SafeNet and Symantec (SYMC).Vasco stock currently trades at about 26, down from an all-time high of 44.25 in October 2007.Dougherty's Maxa says Vasco's Digipass for Apps (DPA) product generates a new revenue stream."It secures mobile banking within the mobile app itself, kind of behind the scenes," Maxa said. "The user may not even know it's there. It's early, but it is being adopted and should help them gain traction in the U.S."Several banks have upgraded or are in the process of upgrading to their PIN pad tokens," Maxa said. "They're now seeing banks upgrade to their new CrontoSign technology, which is easier to use than their PIN pad tokens. Rabobank placed the largest order in the company's history for this technology, and several other large banks are trialing it. The success of Vasco's e-signature technology is due in part to its ability to prevent man-in-the-middle and man-in-the-browser type attacks."How An Attack WorksHunt says a man-in-the-middle attack involves a hacker essentially taking over a banking transaction, changing the payee and amount."For example, you think you are sending $100 to your mother in Kansas, and they change the transaction to instead send $1,000 to Eastern Europe," Hunt said. "By using a tamper-proof, high-definition color QR (Quick Response) code in the process, it becomes extremely easy for the bank customer to see the true transaction details and then verify them."Governments are eyeing Vasco's technology, as well."The Singapore government is offering citizens a free authentication token, named OneKey, using our technology so that citizens can utilize two-factor authentication to have a more secure experience" accessing government applications online, Hunt said."In Belgium, the government has a similar vision of allowing citizens to use their government-issued ID to verify their identity, but they want to take advantage of the large number of card readers that are already in use by citizens today," Hunt said.Maxa sees Singapore as "probably a bigger near-term revenue opportunity of the two, as Belgium is in the very early stages."

Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com (JD) on Tuesday unexpectedly reported a fourth-quarter profit and better-than-expected revenue growth. But its morning breakout ended badly while shares of its larger rival hit a record low.JD.com, which came public last year, reported adjusted earnings per share of 1 cent, beating forecasts for a 2-cent loss and reversing a year-earlier 1-cent loss. The company report a GAAP loss of 5 cents a share. Revenue was $5.6 billion vs. Wall Street forecasts of $5.3 billion. That was a 73% increase in local currency terms. The 68%-69% increase in U.S. dollars was the best in six quarters."Our commitment to providing the best e-commerce experience for Chinese consumers enabled us to deliver excellent results in the fourth quarter," said Richard Liu, founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of JD.com. "Our growing reputation for product authenticity and amazingly fast delivery drove very encouraging increases in total active customers and total fulfilled orders."JD, which has an Amazon.com (AMZN)-like direct sales service, reported gross merchandise value shot up 119% in Q4, with customer accounts up 104% to 96.6 million. But costs rose 68% in local currency terms to $4.9 billion.For the current Q1, JD.com sees revenue rising 54%-58% in local currency terms to about 35.3 billion renminbi, or $5.563 billion. That's fractionally higher than estimates for $5.556 billion.JD.com priced its May 2014 IPO at 19 a share. The stock rose to a 33.10 peak on Aug. 27. Shares sold off, losing one-third of their value, but have consolidated to form a cup-with-handle base.JD shares rose as high as 29.90 in the stock market today, above a buy point of 28.59. But the stock erased those gains as the overall market retreated. JD closed down 2.2% to27.53.JD.com is a key rival of Alibaba (BABA). Messaging giant Tencent (TCEHY), Alibaba's archrival, owns a stake in JD.com, which uses Tencent services to drive traffic and sales. JD and Tencent both recently closed a stake in Chinese auto information website BitAuto (BITA).Alibaba shares fell 2.9% to 81.58 after sinking as low as 80.03. That decisively undercut the Oct. 15 post-IPO low of 82.81.According to a late Monday report in the Wall Street Journal, many orders on the the e-commerce giant sited are fake, a practice known as "brushing," as a way to boost sellers' presence.Meanwhile, Chairman Jack Ma pledged full cooperation with Taiwanese authorities. On Monday, Taiwan ordered the e-commerce giant to cease operations within six months over various Alibaba actions. That sent Alibaba stock down 1.1% to 84 on Monday.Yahoo (YHOO), which plans on spinning off its remaining Alibaba stake in separate company, fell 3.4% to 63.05, its lowest close since late October.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

Alibaba Group's (BABA) profit margins are slipping as it spends to adapt its e-commerce platform to mobile apps, but investments should pay off as Goldman Sachs forecasts mobile revenue to overtake nonmobile revenue in 2017.China's e-commerce leader last week reported fiscal Q4 revenue growth of 45% and said that it had processed $97 billion in gross merchandise volume (GMV), up 40% from the year-earlier quarter. Its platforms, including Taobao and Tmall, handle about 80% of China's e-commerce.In the March quarter, mobile accounted for 51% of GMV, up from 27% in the year-earlier period and 42% in the prior quarter. Q4 marked the first quarter where mobile contributed more to total GMV than desktop usage. Desktop GMV declined year over year for the first time.Alibaba ended Q4 with 289 million active mobile buyers, said Goldman Sachs analyst Piyush Mubayi in a research report Friday. Mubayi upgraded Alibaba to a buy rating."Alibaba's Q4 results set aside fears of slowing GMV and concerns on monetization," said Mubayi. "Spending has been moving to mobile at a pace that has exceeded initial expectations."We expect this trend to remain unrelenting, given the transition in the wireless infrastructure in China on (4G network) rollout and the opportunities in smaller cities and rural China."Alibaba's fastest-growing categories in Q4 were car accessories, dietary supplements, furniture decoration and household products.Analysts have had concerns over Alibaba's aggressive investments, rising competition from companies such as JD.com (JD) and Tencent (TCEHY), and a government investigation into alleged counterfeit merchandise sold on Alibaba platforms.No Word On Alipay SpinoffIn the March quarter, Alibaba posted an EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) margin of 49%, below estimates of 52%. Management said that investments in new business initiatives, including cloud computing and mobile, weighed on EBITDA margins.Alibaba's executives had nothing to say on a possible spinoff of its payments business. Alipay is China's leading PC and mobile payment tool."We expect Taobao to remain as the major mobile traffic generator, given its leading app penetration nationwide, while midterm GMV pressure remains for Tmall as Alibaba management executes on its new merchant selection strategy," Jefferies analyst Cynthia Meng said in a report.Alibaba announced a new chief executive. Daniel Zhang, currently chief operating officer, who has been with the company for eight years, will be the new CEO. He succeeds Jonathan Lu, who replaced Alibaba founder Jack Ma as CEO about two years ago.Alibaba, meanwhile, has taken a more than 9% stake in Zulily. It is the latest of several investments by the China e-commerce king in U.S.-based e-commerce firms.Seattle-based Zulily (ZU) is an online retailer focused on women's and kids' merchandise. Zulily stock jumped to a three-month high Monday on the news.

Alibaba Group stock jumped 7.5% Thursday after China's e-commerce leader reported quarterly earnings that alleviated worries about the company, which is fighting battles on multiple fronts. Jason Weiner is like Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers.
Season after season, he keeps performing at a high level.

Since Feb. 2, 2007, when Weiner became the signal caller for the now $1.3 billion Fidelity Growth Discovery Fund and its adviser-sold twin $2.8 billion Advisor Equity Growth Fund , Growth Discovery has notched an 8.48% average annual gain vs. 7.03% for the S&P 500. Its performance ranks in the top 30% of its large-cap growth peers, tracked by Morningstar Inc.
Weiner has used the same approach for most if not all of his tenure, he says. He seeks undervalued growth stories and stocks with potential for price-earnings expansion, avoiding overly costly names.
Weiner, 45 years old, talked with IBD from his office in Boston about how he invests.
IBD: Jason, if you ever had a mentor, who was it?

Weiner: I've had tons of mentors. On the rare occasions when (Fidelity) rolls me out to meet MBAs visiting Fidelity, I tell them they should find a mentor, either outside their workplace or inside, or preferably both.

It's super important, going back to when I was 15 and had my first job. I got it from a family friend, Lou, who was a great influence. It was Lou Nargiso, and he owned a gas station-auto repair shop. He was a World War II vet, and he learned auto repair in the army.

He was a very well-educated person and philosophical. He liked to debate things. Everyone who worked for Lou was very loyal to him, as was he to them. His shop was also kind of a clubhouse for his World War II vet buddies, and I hung out with them. Good times!
IBD: And at Fidelity?

Weiner: At Fidelity, Will Danoff (manager of Fidelity's $111.1 billion Contrafund , $28.9 billion Advisor New Insights , $6.4 billion Series Opportunistic Insights and $884.8 million Advisor Series Opportunistic Insights has been a great mentor.

I don't remember exactly when it kicked off. It might have been around 1993. We were both on a train. Will was going to southern Connecticut, visiting his parents. We sat next to each other. I worked for him later. I gained a lot of wisdom. Will is super focused on studying each decade, understanding monster stocks in each decade, and being in the elephant-hunting business — hunting stocks that go on to make monster gains.
If you owned Dell in 1990, for the next 10 years nothing else mattered. It's the beauty of incredible growth stories. Will was focused on that, and I have adopted that strategy.
IBD: Overall, you look for undervalued growth stories and stocks with potential for price-earnings expansion, right?
Weiner: You only get paid for two things with growth stocks. First, for P-E expansion. Second, for underlying earnings growth of the companies you invest in.
Typically, I focus on the growth rate of companies. That's where fundamental research can bring value. And I try to leverage Fidelity's research engine a lot.
It's a little harder to predict P-E.
IBD: And you try to avoid valuations that are too high, correct?
Weiner: If you can enter a name you like when there's controversy or doubt that casts its P-E lower, that's a great opportunity.
IBD: Give me an example, please.
Weiner: The best in recent years is Facebook (FB), after Facebook botched its IPO.
The stock had gone public (at 38) and traded down immediately. It bottomed around 17 even though the company was doing great. But there were clouds of controversy that pummeled the stock.
I bought after the IPO. I didn't buy it all on one day. My (average price per share) was in the 20s.

While the stock was going down, the company was rolling out newsfeed ads. It seems like ancient history, but newsfeed ads are relatively new. About the time of the IPO, they stopped relying on ads for PC-based service and shifted to newsfeed ads that appeared on mobile devices. It was a fundamental transformation of their business model. That's Facebook's story today.
IBD: Should people think of Growth Discovery as a GARP (growth at a reasonable price) strategy?

Weiner: A lot of the fund would be recognizable as a GARP basket. That's OK. But in addition, I try to buy the best growth names in the market, the ones that are going to turn into big, sustainable, valuable franchises. That's a little different from GARP.

My top 40 names are 65% of my assets. Not every name will become a brand-new, unbelievable franchise. Some already have great franchises. Some will become great. But if you look at every decade — and I know this from some of the publications that William O'Neil sends me — in the '60s, '70s, '80s, '90s and so on, and look at the monster stocks, there are never that many. I try to buy those sorts of names.
IBD: You are allowed to invest in any market-cap size, but the fund has been large-cap oriented for a long time. Its heaviest weighting was in megacaps as of Sept. 30. Why those, why U.S. ones?
Weiner: Let's take the U.S. piece first. The U.S. economy is doing better than the average developed nation's, so it's fortuitous to be U.S. investors in this day.
And why so many megacaps? If you look at Internet models, the (successful) ones are global, scalable, enjoy incredible network effects and are viral. That's what we want.
I point to Facebook. The biggest companies, like that, enjoy increased returns as they get bigger.

If you were a manufacturer 50 years ago, you might have experienced decreasing returns for every single additional widget you made. They had to be sold at lower margins to incent the market to buy your product. In the Internet age, it's the opposite: increased returns.
The other thing about the Internet is that it's a winner-takes-the-most dynamic. Google (GOOGL) is the leader in search. That is a winner-takes-all battle, and they won.

It's to be determined in the OTA (online travel agency) space. You've got Facebook, Expedia (EXPE), TripAdvisor (TRIP) and a bunch of other ones. (This may also turn into a winner-takes-all space.) That's why we haven't invested in Priceline (PCLN). I have no skin in that game.
IBD: Why did you boost your Apple (AAPL) weighting to 5.8% as of Oct. 31 from less than 1% as of March 31 and 2.3% as of June 30?

Weiner: Full disclosure: I have not done a great job trading Apple in the last five years. I give myself low marks on that one. I can make a long list of Apple's positives and negatives. I've focused on the negatives in the last five years. I'm not going to do that any more.
I live two blocks from an Apple store. When the iPhone 6 came out there was a line around the block. It was crazy. I can't ignore that.

I could lecture about how smartphones are fully penetrated and the rate of innovation is slowing down. And how Android has outshipped Apple iOS five to one and usually the volume leader wins in tech. Actually, it always does! But the negatives haven't mattered (to Apple's stock performance).
IBD: So you've decided — at least for the moment — that all is not lost for Apple?

Weiner: One of the key buckets of stock I've avoided is large-cap tech legacy players: Oracle (ORCL), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Microsoft (MSFT) and on and on. I generally underweight them. I'm mindful that they have secular challenges. When that happens, you never know if they will catch up. IBM (IBM) for years faced them but somehow always punched out good earnings. But that may be changing. Last quarter was terrible for them.

When secular challenges catch up to a company, it's all over. In the 1990s, I was a tech analyst covering Compaq, Tandem, Digital, Stratus, Data General. They faced secular challenges. When the wave hit, they fell over. They don't exist now (as independent companies).
Apple is a huge, good legacy story relative to other legacy players. That's another justification for owning Apple.
IBD: You held Illumina (ILMN) as of Oct. 31. You're a fan of the outlook for gene sequencing, right?
Weiner: Yes. Illumina is an incredible company, helping to unlock the secrets of sequencing genomes for just $1,000. The way we practice medicine is changing because of companies like Illumina.
If you look backwards, people were doing one human genome. Now they're sequencing thousands. In the future, you will have your genome when you go to the doctor. That's where Illumina comes in.
IBD: Will Alexion (ALXN) remain a play on a single drug, Soliris?

Weiner: My Alexion thesis (as of my latest disclosure) was this: they are a super orphan-drug company. They only go after indications with small patient populations, where they get a lot of money for life-saving drugs.
They've increased the number of indications Soliris is sold for. And behind that there is another drug they're hoping for FDA approval for, for a new set of indications.

It's hard for society to say it will not pay for a drug, and your child will live for only a couple of years. If society pays for the drug, your child will have a normal outcome. It's a big ethics debate. But bottom line: countries are paying for these drugs.
IBD: How similar is Gilead's (GILD) story?

Weiner: They have great risk-reward. They beat the competition. There will be others with cures for hepatitis C. They will get market share. But Gilead will get the majority market share. If you have hep C, you want this drug immediately.

One knock against the drug is that some people don't like to invest in companies that cure a disease. Then the treatment is a one-shot deal. Some people say, 'Isn't it better to develop a treatment for HIV that requires patients to take a pill every day?' But there's still plenty of room for the hep C drug. There are millions of patients who don't have the drug yet.
IBD: Chipotle's (CMG) earnings growth has accelerated for two quarters.
Weiner: It's a great franchise with tons of room for growth. The secret is that people will pay more for food that they think is higher quality.
IBD: What about Sherwin-Williams (SHW)?
Weiner: This is one of the greatest companies that nobody recognizes.

Their paint store franchise is so valuable. They're vertically integrated. Professional painters make their first daily stop at Sherwin-Williams, not Home Depot (HD) or Lowe's (LOW). They know how to treat pros. They have lots of pricing power. Material costs are not a big deal. Most (end users) are people restoring or remodeling homes. It does not depend on home sales.
IBD: What drives Ulta Beauty (ULTA)?

Weiner: What I like about Ulta is that beauty has high emotional content for women. Ulta gives them the ability to walk into a mall-based, completely dedicated beauty retailer and not have to walk halfway across a department store to get to a beauty counter. And Ulta has a growing number of prestige brands. Years ago, prestige brands wouldn't sell through them. Now they do.
Beauty products have high margins. Profits, same-store sales, sales per square foot are all growing.

Last year, profits had actually been muted. The CEO (Mary Dillon) is investing heavily in e-commerce. She told a credible story to the Street about what her investments can do, so people are on board.
IBD: You were a fan of Alibaba (BABA) as of your latest disclosure, right?

Weiner: Alibaba is like the legend with that name. In 100 years, people will talk about (CEO) Jack Ma in those terms. This is the e-commerce leader in China. Full stop. China is a big market that is growing.

Jack Ma has done a very good job of building a huge business with massive gross merchandise value. He's attracted merchants with a low take rate. That means for a small or medium business, Alibaba is a great tool to grow your business.
He also has G Mall, the place where global brands can sell in a safe place where there are no counterfeits there.
And he's got payments and financial services in his back pocket.

Alibaba's gross merchandise value is larger than Amazon (AMZN) and eBay's (EBAY) combined.Jason Weiner is like Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers.Season after season, he keeps performing at a high level.Since Feb. 2, 2007, when Weiner became the signal caller for the now $1.3 billion Fidelity Growth Discovery Fund and its adviser-sold twin $2.8 billion Advisor Equity Growth Fund , Growth Discovery has notched an 8.48% average annual gain vs. 7.03% for the S&P 500. Its performance ranks in the top 30% of its large-cap growth peers, tracked by Morningstar Inc.Weiner has used the same approach for most if not all of his tenure, he says. He seeks undervalued growth stories and stocks with potential for price-earnings expansion, avoiding overly costly names.Weiner, 45 years old, talked with IBD from his office in Boston about how he invests.IBD: Jason, if you ever had a mentor, who was it?Weiner: I've had tons of mentors. On the rare occasions when (Fidelity) rolls me out to meet MBAs visiting Fidelity, I tell them they should find a mentor, either outside their workplace or inside, or preferably both.It's super important, going back to when I was 15 and had my first job. I got it from a family friend, Lou, who was a great influence. It was Lou Nargiso, and he owned a gas station-auto repair shop. He was a World War II vet, and he learned auto repair in the army.He was a very well-educated person and philosophical. He liked to debate things. Everyone who worked for Lou was very loyal to him, as was he to them. His shop was also kind of a clubhouse for his World War II vet buddies, and I hung out with them. Good times!IBD: And at Fidelity?Weiner: At Fidelity, Will Danoff (manager of Fidelity's $111.1 billion Contrafund , $28.9 billion Advisor New Insights , $6.4 billion Series Opportunistic Insights and $884.8 million Advisor Series Opportunistic Insights has been a great mentor.I don't remember exactly when it kicked off. It might have been around 1993. We were both on a train. Will was going to southern Connecticut, visiting his parents. We sat next to each other. I worked for him later. I gained a lot of wisdom. Will is super focused on studying each decade, understanding monster stocks in each decade, and being in the elephant-hunting business — hunting stocks that go on to make monster gains.If you owned Dell in 1990, for the next 10 years nothing else mattered. It's the beauty of incredible growth stories. Will was focused on that, and I have adopted that strategy.IBD: Overall, you look for undervalued growth stories and stocks with potential for price-earnings expansion, right?Weiner: You only get paid for two things with growth stocks. First, for P-E expansion. Second, for underlying earnings growth of the companies you invest in.Typically, I focus on the growth rate of companies. That's where fundamental research can bring value. And I try to leverage Fidelity's research engine a lot.It's a little harder to predict P-E.IBD: And you try to avoid valuations that are too high, correct?Weiner: If you can enter a name you like when there's controversy or doubt that casts its P-E lower, that's a great opportunity.IBD: Give me an example, please.Weiner: The best in recent years is Facebook (FB), after Facebook botched its IPO.The stock had gone public (at 38) and traded down immediately. It bottomed around 17 even though the company was doing great. But there were clouds of controversy that pummeled the stock.I bought after the IPO. I didn't buy it all on one day. My (average price per share) was in the 20s.While the stock was going down, the company was rolling out newsfeed ads. It seems like ancient history, but newsfeed ads are relatively new. About the time of the IPO, they stopped relying on ads for PC-based service and shifted to newsfeed ads that appeared on mobile devices. It was a fundamental transformation of their business model. That's Facebook's story today.IBD: Should people think of Growth Discovery as a GARP (growth at a reasonable price) strategy?Weiner: A lot of the fund would be recognizable as a GARP basket. That's OK. But in addition, I try to buy the best growth names in the market, the ones that are going to turn into big, sustainable, valuable franchises. That's a little different from GARP.My top 40 names are 65% of my assets. Not every name will become a brand-new, unbelievable franchise. Some already have great franchises. Some will become great. But if you look at every decade — and I know this from some of the publications that William O'Neil sends me — in the '60s, '70s, '80s, '90s and so on, and look at the monster stocks, there are never that many. I try to buy those sorts of names.IBD: You are allowed to invest in any market-cap size, but the fund has been large-cap oriented for a long time. Its heaviest weighting was in megacaps as of Sept. 30. Why those, why U.S. ones?Weiner: Let's take the U.S. piece first. The U.S. economy is doing better than the average developed nation's, so it's fortuitous to be U.S. investors in this day.And why so many megacaps? If you look at Internet models, the (successful) ones are global, scalable, enjoy incredible network effects and are viral. That's what we want.I point to Facebook. The biggest companies, like that, enjoy increased returns as they get bigger.If you were a manufacturer 50 years ago, you might have experienced decreasing returns for every single additional widget you made. They had to be sold at lower margins to incent the market to buy your product. In the Internet age, it's the opposite: increased returns.The other thing about the Internet is that it's a winner-takes-the-most dynamic. Google (GOOGL) is the leader in search. That is a winner-takes-all battle, and they won.It's to be determined in the OTA (online travel agency) space. You've got Facebook, Expedia (EXPE), TripAdvisor (TRIP) and a bunch of other ones. (This may also turn into a winner-takes-all space.) That's why we haven't invested in Priceline (PCLN). I have no skin in that game.IBD: Why did you boost your Apple (AAPL) weighting to 5.8% as of Oct. 31 from less than 1% as of March 31 and 2.3% as of June 30?Weiner: Full disclosure: I have not done a great job trading Apple in the last five years. I give myself low marks on that one. I can make a long list of Apple's positives and negatives. I've focused on the negatives in the last five years. I'm not going to do that any more.I live two blocks from an Apple store. When the iPhone 6 came out there was a line around the block. It was crazy. I can't ignore that.I could lecture about how smartphones are fully penetrated and the rate of innovation is slowing down. And how Android has outshipped Apple iOS five to one and usually the volume leader wins in tech. Actually, it always does! But the negatives haven't mattered (to Apple's stock performance).IBD: So you've decided — at least for the moment — that all is not lost for Apple?Weiner: One of the key buckets of stock I've avoided is large-cap tech legacy players: Oracle (ORCL), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Microsoft (MSFT) and on and on. I generally underweight them. I'm mindful that they have secular challenges. When that happens, you never know if they will catch up. IBM (IBM) for years faced them but somehow always punched out good earnings. But that may be changing. Last quarter was terrible for them.When secular challenges catch up to a company, it's all over. In the 1990s, I was a tech analyst covering Compaq, Tandem, Digital, Stratus, Data General. They faced secular challenges. When the wave hit, they fell over. They don't exist now (as independent companies).Apple is a huge, good legacy story relative to other legacy players. That's another justification for owning Apple.IBD: You held Illumina (ILMN) as of Oct. 31. You're a fan of the outlook for gene sequencing, right?Weiner: Yes. Illumina is an incredible company, helping to unlock the secrets of sequencing genomes for just $1,000. The way we practice medicine is changing because of companies like Illumina.If you look backwards, people were doing one human genome. Now they're sequencing thousands. In the future, you will have your genome when you go to the doctor. That's where Illumina comes in.IBD: Will Alexion (ALXN) remain a play on a single drug, Soliris?Weiner: My Alexion thesis (as of my latest disclosure) was this: they are a super orphan-drug company. They only go after indications with small patient populations, where they get a lot of money for life-saving drugs.They've increased the number of indications Soliris is sold for. And behind that there is another drug they're hoping for FDA approval for, for a new set of indications.It's hard for society to say it will not pay for a drug, and your child will live for only a couple of years. If society pays for the drug, your child will have a normal outcome. It's a big ethics debate. But bottom line: countries are paying for these drugs.IBD: How similar is Gilead's (GILD) story?Weiner: They have great risk-reward. They beat the competition. There will be others with cures for hepatitis C. They will get market share. But Gilead will get the majority market share. If you have hep C, you want this drug immediately.One knock against the drug is that some people don't like to invest in companies that cure a disease. Then the treatment is a one-shot deal. Some people say, 'Isn't it better to develop a treatment for HIV that requires patients to take a pill every day?' But there's still plenty of room for the hep C drug. There are millions of patients who don't have the drug yet.IBD: Chipotle's (CMG) earnings growth has accelerated for two quarters.Weiner: It's a great franchise with tons of room for growth. The secret is that people will pay more for food that they think is higher quality.IBD: What about Sherwin-Williams (SHW)?Weiner: This is one of the greatest companies that nobody recognizes.Their paint store franchise is so valuable. They're vertically integrated. Professional painters make their first daily stop at Sherwin-Williams, not Home Depot (HD) or Lowe's (LOW). They know how to treat pros. They have lots of pricing power. Material costs are not a big deal. Most (end users) are people restoring or remodeling homes. It does not depend on home sales.IBD: What drives Ulta Beauty (ULTA)?Weiner: What I like about Ulta is that beauty has high emotional content for women. Ulta gives them the ability to walk into a mall-based, completely dedicated beauty retailer and not have to walk halfway across a department store to get to a beauty counter. And Ulta has a growing number of prestige brands. Years ago, prestige brands wouldn't sell through them. Now they do.Beauty products have high margins. Profits, same-store sales, sales per square foot are all growing.Last year, profits had actually been muted. The CEO (Mary Dillon) is investing heavily in e-commerce. She told a credible story to the Street about what her investments can do, so people are on board.IBD: You were a fan of Alibaba (BABA) as of your latest disclosure, right?Weiner: Alibaba is like the legend with that name. In 100 years, people will talk about (CEO) Jack Ma in those terms. This is the e-commerce leader in China. Full stop. China is a big market that is growing.Jack Ma has done a very good job of building a huge business with massive gross merchandise value. He's attracted merchants with a low take rate. That means for a small or medium business, Alibaba is a great tool to grow your business.He also has G Mall, the place where global brands can sell in a safe place where there are no counterfeits there.And he's got payments and financial services in his back pocket.Alibaba's gross merchandise value is larger than Amazon (AMZN) and eBay's (EBAY) combined.

I believe in the impossible because no one else does.
Florence Griffith Joyner, Olympic sprinter

When you innovate, you've got to be prepared for everyone telling you you're nuts.
Larry Ellison, Oracle CEO

I haven't the slightest idea how to change people, but still I keep a long list of prospective candidates just in case I should ever figure it out.
David Sedaris, author

To know what is right and not to do it is the worst cowardice.
Confucius, philosopher

Success seems to be connected with action. Successful people keep moving. They make mistakes, but they don't quit.
Conrad Hilton, hotelier
